awd_titl_txt: Submanifolds and Foliations in Riemannian Manifolds
awd_abstract_narration:
Differential geometry is the study of the geometry of spaces.  Sometimes these spaces exist as physical objects such as the surface of planet or a cell, or the universe itself; sometimes they appear as abstract spaces in applied situations, such as the set of all possible states of a physical system, the set of possible configurations of a machine, or the set of strategies of a group of players in the stock market. In these situations, it is often important to find and study the properties of objects inside these spaces that are optimal in some sense: for example, the shortest way to move between two configurations, or the surface that minimizes area or surface tension. Sometimes these geometric sub-objects come in families (e.g., foliations that slice the space into thin pieces), and it is important to study not just each of these pieces by itself, but the whole family as a unique entity. This project will study several instances of these important and very natural objects, and draw new bridges between these geometric concepts and other more abstract areas of mathematics.

The main goal of the project is to study certain structures of Riemannian manifolds such as singular Riemannian foliations and closed minimal submanifolds, and relate them to the geometry and topology of the ambient space. In the study of singular Riemannian foliations, the main focus will be on laying new theoretical ground (e.g., continuing the development of an invariant theory in this context) and applying these concepts in different areas, such as producing new manifolds with positive and non-negative curvature, or exhibiting new immersed minimal hypersurfaces in round spheres and projective spaces. In the study of closed minimal submanifolds, the main focus will be on the index of such objects, especially in the two extreme cases of closed geodesics and minimal hypersurfaces. The PI will continue working on a conjecture of Berger on manifolds with all geodesics closed, and on a conjecture of Marques-Neves-Schoen on minimal hypersurfaces in manifolds with positive Ricci curvature. In the first case, the plan is to improve the understanding of the equivariant Morse theory on the free loop space of spaces with all geodesics closed. In the second case, the PI will continue to develop tools such as virtual immersions, recently developed by the PI, which could have independent interest.

por.por_cntn:
Riemannian manifolds are geometric objects that are widely used to model several physical spaces (soap films, elastic sheets, surface of cells, the universe itself) as well as abstract spaces such as the space of configurations of a system, a space of probability distributions, or the space of strategies of a game. The goal of my project was to understand the interaction between the geometry of a Riemannian manifold, with the presence of certain structures in it, such as singular riemannian foliations or compact minimal submanifolds.


Singular Riemannian foliations are ways to partition a manifold into subspaces that are at a constant distance from one another. The main success of the present program has been in producing a very precise theory for the local structure of singular riemannian foliations. It was known that such a local study is equivalent to understanding the structure of singular Riemannian foliations on round spheres. In a sequence of joint works with Ricardo Mendes, we proved that understanding singular riemannian foliations in spheres and their properties, is equivalent to understand "mirror" properties of certain families of polynomials called "Laplacian algebras". This result opens the door to using algebraic techniques in what has been so far a purely geometric topic, and it also allows to formulate new questions, or re-contextualize old ones, using the algebraic framework. In several works, Ricardo and I showed that these novel Laplacian algebras are often related to well known and well-studied structures such as Jordan algebras, whose classification has allowed us to produce structure results not known before.


This correspondence between foliations and polynomial algebras mimics the classical Invariant Theory, but in some sense it is stronger than that, since unlike Invariant Theory, our theory strikes a complete equivalence between the geometric and algebraic picture. In fact, the first applications of our theory has been to answer a number of open questions in Classical and Computational Invariant theory.


Besides this line of work, I have also worked on other projects. With Marco Mazzucchelli, for example, we studied convex contact spheres. These are special spheres in space, equipped with an extra piece of data called a contact form, which appears naturally in certain physical systems. A contact form gives rise to a Reeb flow, which is a flow that moves the points of the sphere around, within the sphere itself. In some special cases, the flow is periodic, i.e. there is a point in time in which all points of the sphere flow back to their original position; in this case, the convex manifold is called Besse. There are not many known examples of Besse convex contact spheres (the known ones belong to a family of so-called "contact ellipsoids") but on the other hand there are virtually results that quantify to what extent how rigid the Besse condition might be. In out joint work, we prove that if a convect contact sphere is Besse, then the Reeb flow has many similarities with that of some contact ellipsoid. In other words, even if more convex Besse contact spheres existed, they would not be too dissimilar from the known examples.


All the results obtained as part of this project have been disseminated in numerous conferences and talks in the US, Canada, South America and Europe.
